channel.title: BBC News | News Front Page | UK Edition
channel.description: Updated every minute of every day - FOR PERSONAL USE ONLY

item.title: Rooney inspires England
item.description: Wayne Rooney's goals give England a win over Croatia to give them a place in Euro 2004 quarter finals.

item.title: Iran seizes UK vessels and crew
item.description: UK diplomats hold talks with the Iranian authorities after three British naval vessels are seized in Iranian waters.

item.title: Millions face rail travel misery
item.description: Up to 15,000 workers on Network Rail and London Underground call a joint 24-hour strike over pay.

item.title: Private craft makes space history
item.description: SpaceShipOne has flown into the history books as the first non-governmental manned craft to reach space.

item.title: Battle joined on EU constitution
item.description: Tony Blair defends the EU constitution deal but is accused of selling out Britain's interests by the Tories.

item.title: England fan 'nowhere near riots'
item.description: An England fan given a two-year jail term for rioting in Portugal says he is innocent and has been victimised.

item.title: Ex-officer 'leads Saudi al-Qaeda'
item.description: An ex-Saudi policeman has become leader of the al-Qaeda militant group in Saudi Arabia, media reports say.

item.title: Korea in Iraq hostage ultimatum
item.description: Militants demand South Korea withdraw from Iraq, but Seoul says it will not cave in despite threats to kill a hostage.

item.title: £1m for Hatfield victim's family
item.description: The widow and two children of one of the four victims of the Hatfield rail crash are awarded £1m compensation.

item.title: Navratilova storms through
item.description: Martina Navratilova rolls back the years to sweep aside Catalina Castano 6-0 6-1.

item.title: Football: France go through
item.description: A Thierry Henry brace puts France into the quarter-finals as winners of Group B.

item.title: Tennis: Ivanisevic wins on return
item.description: Goran Ivanisevic stuns 31st seed Mikhail Youzhny in his first match at Wimbledon for three years.

item.title: Clashes in rebel-held Ivory Coast
item.description: Rival factions battle in the rebel headquarters, as President Gbagbo pledges to revive the peace process.

item.title: Korea appeals for hostage release
item.description: South Korea urges the release of a hostage threatened with death in Iraq, as a deadline set by his captors expires.

item.title: Clinton: 'Demons' led to affair
item.description: Bill Clinton says his relationship with Monica Lewinsky came at a time when he was under huge pressure as president.

item.title: Battle grips south Russian region
item.description: Heavily armed gunmen attack the regional police HQ and other targets in Ingushetia, close to Chechnya.

item.title: Generals face Abu Ghraib hearings
item.description: A judge says the defence team of a soldier accused of abusing Iraqi prisoners can question top US generals.

item.title: Tigers accuse Sri Lanka military
item.description: Tamil Tigers accuse the security forces of helping a breakaway commander who split from the rebel movement in March.

item.title: BBQ shootings suspect found dead
item.description: A man accused of murdering his wife and her sister in a shooting at a family barbecue is found dead in prison.

item.title: Pair arrested in murder inquiry
item.description: A man and a woman are still being held by detectives investigating the killing of a man in County Armagh.

item.title: Father slams 'lenient' sentence
item.description: The father of a boy killed by a hit-and-run driver high on drink and drugs hits out at an 11-year jail sentence.

item.title: Ex-footballer guilty of presenter attack
item.description: Former Wales footballer Mark Aizlewood is told to pay £1,800 in fines and costs after pushing a TV journalist down a flight of stairs.

item.title: Vivendi ex-boss in police custody
item.description: The former boss of the French media giant is being held by police investigating allegations of 'financial misappropriation' at the firm.

item.title: No 10 rejects smacking ban move
item.description: Tony Blair does not believe there should be a law against parents smacking their children, his spokesman says.

item.title: Tories plan big changes for NHS
item.description: The Tories have pledged to scrap all central targets for NHS hospitals, including waiting lists.

item.title: Languages may get higher profile
item.description: Language learning could become a required subject in Tomlinson's overhaul of the English curriculum.

item.title: Antarctic hero 'reunited' with cat
item.description: This month, the carpenter on Shackleton's ill-fated Endurance ship and his beloved tabby, Mrs Chippy, will be "reunited", when a statue of the cat is placed on his grave.

item.title: 'Wireless pebbles' track glaciers
item.description: Scientists monitoring the behaviour of glaciers have been using wireless sensors for the first time.

item.title: Potter film's US chart reign ends
item.description: Ben Stiller's new comedy Dodgeball knocks the third Harry Potter film from the top of the US box office.

item.title: Is there a countryside crisis?
item.description: The number of homeless people in England's rural areas is now increasing more rapidly than in large towns and cities. Is there a crisis in the countryside?
